Posts.Content: Hi. I started on zoladex and letrazole three months ago. When my surgeon suggested hormone therapy he gave me leaflets for both drugs. I took them with me when I went to my GP for my first prescription.  The doctor arranged the DEXA scan, only after i asked and she read up on it, got the test weeks ago but no one interested in the results, not been received at GP and I was told to phone the hospital myself if I wanted them. I asked the nurse about my cholesterol as the leaflets said my treatment can cause high cholesterol.  The nurse asked where I got the leaflet as if I was being paranoid.   The leaflets on individual hormone therapies are available from breast cancer care and it might be useful to get the leaflet, see what you need checked and ask your GP. I was discharged from onc and told my GP will take care of my treatment now. But I really feel it's up to me to make sure everything is covered as the GP's are really not that interested. Take care Keeker
Posts.Title: bone scan question

Posts.Content: Hi Jacky I was unemployed when diagnosed so have been looking for work. Office jobs. They are not allowed to ask health questions at interview. You only have to declare it after you have been offered the position. Several job applications include a section on disability but my understanding is you don't have to complete this part until you have been offered the job, and only to be used by HR or occupational health assessment, however many large employers have positive discrimination so you get a guaranteed interview if you declare it.  However the reality is quite different. I was asked at interview what I had been doing for the last six months. How could I answer that without mentioning cancer? I was back out on the street within five mins. The legislation says if you have cancer, or have had cancer. So you are covered by the legislation whether you agree or not. No one will use the word cured. Even people who had cancer many many years ago are still covered by the legislation.   You are not classed as disabled for everything. You don't qualify for the free bus pass or blue badge for example.  It is so very confusing,  as I am single I can work 16 hours and get working tax credit to make up my income I think. I just think I will use the legislation where it helps me.  Take care Keekers
Posts.Title: Cancer diagnosis = disability?

Posts.Content: Hi ladies. I live in Scotland so didn't need the card for free prescriptions,  however as I am on a low income (ESA) I completed a form which gave me a certificate for free health treatment.  Not sure name but you can google help with health costs. This can be registered writh pharmacy and gives you other free medication.  free NHS dentist and glasses. This is UK wide. The main thing for me is I get expenses for every hospital visit. I was treated at a hospital 60 miles away and would not have been able to have rads if I had to pay to travel costs. I worked out it would have cost over £400 for the three weeks.  Take care Keekers
Posts.Title: Cancer diagnosis = disability?

Posts.Content: Hi Trudi Please don't feel awful about your anger. It is completely justified and in that situation I would feel angry that I didn't take the opportunity to scream in her face about what a completely self centered uncaring sorry excuse for a human being she is, but's that just me. Having said that, like you, I am making excuses for my family for managing to completely ignore the fact I have cancer. I really do not care about their reasons. I have no emotional energy left for other people's excuses.  We are all trapped in our politeness smiling through the pain so you just come on here as much as you need to rant.  Take care Keekers
Posts.Title: I am experienceing anger at my family andfeel awful about it

Posts.Content: Hi Lynne 41. I am completely with you on the adverts. I think we have a kind of PTSD. Right back there. I didn't need chemo but the one where the man falls after being told he has cancer was me on the 28th jan. The reality is we are alone going through treatment but the lucky ones like yourself have close support. I was recently asked "would I like to help fight cancer" by a  fundraiser.  My first thought was to say I am already fighting cancer thanks very much. My emotions are very raw and all these adverts are driving me crazy, some take me right back to the feelings I had months ago. I did bake for the macmillan coffee morning but refused to attend any coffee mornings as I won't be the token cancer patient.  I just hope these feelings will fade over time but it still surprises me every time I am forced back to those days, those feelings, that pain.  So much of the damage of breast cancer seems to be mental more than physical, Take care Keeker
Posts.Title: tv advert

Posts.Content: Hi Maddog. It's weird isn't it? You want to get on but as it gets closer you get more stressed not less. I was like that before onc apt, and rads, and starting hormone therapy. You don't say what you are seeing onc for, I got rads and at the first appointment they examined me to check I was healing ok, they discussed rads and mentioned my hormone therapy,  that was a lot for one appointment.   I had already decided not to take hormone therapy until after rads so I had a list of questions written out. Unfortunately I was so stressed I can't understand my own notes when I wrote down the replies. I also took the chance to get the oncologist to run all my figures through his computer to see my personal results, it helped making my decisions. I got the time scales I could expect to wait which was great. I hope your appointment goes well,  Take care Keeker
Posts.Title: What to expect?

Posts.Content: Hi Jacky. Sorry you are still feeling bad. Did the nurse pat you on the head on the way out the door. There are a lot of "probably, might be and it's  normal" in this game. I don't think the nurse can really make a diagnosis but she checked you out and it obviously wasn't whatever what she was checking for. It is very frustrating when you don't get a definite answer as to what has caused your symptoms and this fobbing us off with 'probablys' is often the best we can hope for.  If you are really  worried about this then I would speak to your BCN and possibly try and see your GP. You have had a big op and it can take ages to get over, both the physical operation and also the emotional stress. I hope you feel better soon.  Take care Keeker
Posts.Title: anaesthetic

Posts.Content: Hi Willow 74. I have had all my treatment on NHS but like you I'm in Scotland and although there is a hospital 18 miles from my home I got most of my treatment in Edinburgh. A round trip of 120 miles. When I had problems my BCN only worked 3 days a week and every problem was met with "pop in and I'll take a look" so I contacted my local hospital myself and asked to speak to the BCN there.i had loads of problems after surgery and she was always there even though technically I was not her patient. After rads I insisted all my care be transferred to local hospital and it was no problem. Maybe you could try that. The nurse is not going to turn you away and at least you will have that very important support.  Take care Keeker
Posts.Title: Transfer from private care to NHS

Posts.Content: Woke up thinking about work, just finished first week of new job, near home, nice people, don't care I have cancer. After a year I didn't think it would happen.
Posts.Title: YAY!!

Posts.Content: Hi  I am the same, I want to know, some don't.  When I went to the clinic I was told there was a shaddow they wanted to check out. When I was getting my mammogram I asked the lady to show me what she was looking at. She showed me the calcification on my scan, this had never been mentioned,  I asked for a copy of my pathology report and got the BCC leaflet "understanding your pathology report". It turned out I had IDC, DCIS and malignant calcification. Only the IDC had been mentioned up to that point. It made no difference to my treatment but it has made a difference to my decision to take my hormone treatment. I did think I would refuse this treatment but after finding out there was three cancers in there I will carry on. There was limited time at appointments and they only mentioned the most important one. I would agree that the best thing is to write down any questions you have, your BCN can answer a lot and you do forget a lot during appointments and kick yourself on the way home that you forgot to ask things. If you want copies of reports and doctors letters just ask. I found mine very useful.  Take care Keeker
Posts.Title: Slightly confused!

Posts.Content: Hi Smurphy welcome. I am sorry you find yourself here. This is the worse time. Waiting and trying to get your head round it all. Your emotions are all over the place. Constant aches and pains, poking yourself to check but most of all hoping it's all a big mistake.    You can't really start fighting until you know what you are fighting against. I didn't know what questions to ask, and every piece of information I got was forgotten before I even got out the door. I was given the booklet "understanding breast cancer" by my nurse and found it useful in working out what questions I wanted answered. Keep a note pad close by. Write down questions you have. Your breast care nurse can answer a lot and write down answers, you forget a lot. You will be more focused once you know what you are dealing with and have your treatment plan. We are all different, our cancers are all different and so our treatments are different. Just now it's all about coming to terms with having cancer, and dealing with other people and that's not easy,  telling everyone you are fine when screaming inside.  Whatever you feel is normal, take your time and don't push yourself too much. You have had a hugh shock and it's ok to have the wobbles,   I hope you stick around and let us know if we can help. We've all been there.  Take care Keeker
Posts.Title: New to this!

Posts.Content: Hi ladies, there is a lot of debate about this, there's an old thread about milk and other dairy products on here, milk products have a lot of hormones. If you want to check out your own hormone therapy drugs the breast cancer care website has leaflets on them all and they have loads of info. It's a dilemma, take care keeker
Posts.Title: Letrozole and oestrogens in food

Posts.Content: Hi Yvonne. We are in the same place as regards treatment. I was unemployed when diagnosed so no work but looking.  I do feel some people expect me to be the same as before, and with most people I probably am the same but I never tell people my treatment is finished. I am on letrazole with zoladex injections.   This treatment is physically hard but I have had days where I felt such despair,  for no real reason, and it scared me. I spoke to my GP and was told to watch it. Depression is another lovely side effect, so if yours hangs around for a while it might be an idea to see your GP. My biggest problem seems to be that I expect to be the same. I am so frustrated with the tiredness. I do sleep but wake loads of times during the night then wake up feeling tired. I worry about finding a job and not being able to work.  But when I go on interviews it all changes when I say what I have been doing for the last 8 months. I ask myself what I've been doing as well. I finished my rads in May.  I hope you get some sleep Keeker
Posts.Title: Sick of not being able to sleep

Posts.Content: Hi I can't take tamoxifen due to the high risk of blood clots, so I'm on letrozol and zoladex, not too bad, the side effects are there but bearable, there are leaflets on the breast cancer care website for each of the hormone treatments which have loads of information, I didn't agree to start mine until I finished my rads so I would know which treatment caused which side effect. I hope you get the information you need to make your choices, five years is a long time to feel like c**p. take care keeker
Posts.Title: Alternative to Tamoxifen?

Posts.Content: I'm a year next week, still pale blue,
Posts.Title: blue boobs

Posts.Content: Hi April I am so sorry to hear your friends news, it's so difficult having to deal with things like this when your friend needs your help. Sometimes you have to wonder what kind of people could treat people this way in these situations.  You could possibly get social services involved,  I think that maybe the helpline might be able to give you some advice.  Or even email your MP and the head of the council involved. Your friend needs to be near the people who care about her. With all the attention on cancer just now your friends story is the reality of what it can be like. Not the sunny happy picture we keep seeing on tv.  Don't give up, threaten to expose their treatment of your friend, contact any cancer charity in the area that offers help, there must be someone out there who can help, sometimes it's just a case of contacting someone who can get things done, not these jobs worths.  Good luck, Keeker
Posts.Title: months to live. secondary cancer breast

Posts.Content: Hi Bella 69 it sounds like it could be rosacea, Not sure of the spelling.  My dad got it as a side effect of a medication he was on (Non cancer related). it might be worth going to see your GP.  Good luck with the tamoxifen, I'm on Letrozole but it's no picnic. Keeker
Posts.Title: My FACE!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Moll 1967, sorry to hear you are feeling so low, I can't comment on your veins but I still remember how I felt going through rads. The tiredness, so down that getting moving was such a chore. When you are so down physically it is almost impossible to stay strong emotionally, with me it hit half way through rads and lasted for a while afterwards, I cried a lot when I was alone. If I was you I would take pain killers and wait it out, you will get your mojo back but for now just go with the flow and take it very easy. be good to yourself. keeker
Posts.Title: varicose veins

Posts.Content: Hi From reading the many leaflets it would seem that DCIS is usually treated with a mastectomy,  IDC is usually treated with a WLI and rads,  you get the rads to make sure there is nothing left in what's left of your breast. As you have had a mastectomy there's nothing left to zap,  I was not given a choice but when I checked with my oncologist he said the percentages were the same for both treatments. Your cancer was er+ so the tamoxifen is to stop another cancer forming,  it's a hard drug, some people really struggle with the side effects,  there is a leaflet on the breast cancer care website for tamoxifen take a look and write down what you need to know. I can't take it because of the risk of blood clots so I'm taking a different hormone therapy but I think they all thin your bones so I asked for a DEXA bone scan to check my bone density,  that way if I get another next year I can check if my bones have thinned, my treatment can also increase cholesterol so I got that checked as well, I feel we do have to check all this out for ourselves and make sure we know what could happen taking these drugs, no one in my medical team suggested any of these things and I really feel they should have. One lady I went for rads with already developed a blood clot and my friend who had cancer 9 years ago breaks a rib if someone gives her a hug,  which could have been prevented if someone had told her there was a high risk of osteoporosis and given her pills to prevent it. Take care Keeker
Posts.Title: DCIS, MASTECTOMY BUT NO RADIOTHERAPY????
